title: 106_s61
content: The Act of 1999 is known as the "Continued Dumping and Subsidy Offset Act." Congress made findings regarding this Act. Congress finds that injurious dumping and actionable subsidies must be effectively neutralized to protect domestic industries and prevent job and investment loss in the United States. The continued dumping or subsidization of imported products can hinder fair trade conditions and deter domestic producers from reinvesting or rehiring. United States trade laws should be strengthened to ensure the remedial purpose of those laws is achieved, as producers, small businesses, American farmers, and ranchers may struggle to maintain benefits, pay down debt, or remain viable without fair trade conditions. AMENDMENTS TO THE TARIFF ACT OF 1930: Section 754 on Continued Dumping and Subsidy Offset is added to Title VII of the Tariff Act of 1930. The Continued Dumping and Subsidy Offset section of the Tariff Act of 1930 distributes duties to affected domestic producers for qualifying expenditures. An affected domestic producer includes manufacturers, producers, farmers, ranchers, or worker representatives involved in the petition for antidumping or countervailing duty orders. The Tariff Act of 1930 distributes duties to affected domestic producers for qualifying expenditures incurred after the issuance of antidumping or countervailing duty orders. The Commissioner of Customs and the United States International Trade Commission play key roles in this process. The Tariff Act of 1930 allocates duties to domestic producers for qualifying expenditures related to various categories such as plant, equipment, research and development, personnel training, acquisition of technology, healthcare benefits, pension benefits, environmental equipment, raw materials, and working capital. Companies, businesses, or individuals are considered related if they have a connection to each other. The Tariff Act of 1930 assigns duties to domestic producers for qualifying expenses related to different categories. Companies, businesses, or individuals are considered related if there is control or influence between them, either directly or indirectly. Control can be legal or operational, leading to a different behavior compared to non-related parties. The Tariff Act of 1930 assigns duties to domestic producers for qualifying expenses related to different categories. The Commissioner will prescribe procedures for distribution of dumping or subsidies offset, to be made within 60 days after the first day of a fiscal year from duties assessed during the preceding fiscal year. The Commission shall provide a list of affected domestic producers eligible for distribution of antidumping and countervailing duties assessed. The Commission will publish a list of persons supporting a petition for dumping and subsidy offset distribution in the Federal Register at least 30 days before distribution. If identification is not possible, the Commission will consult with the administering authority to determine the petitioner and domestic parties involved in administrative reviews. The Commissioner will distribute funds to eligible domestic producers based on a list obtained from the Commission. Producers must certify their desire to receive the distribution, eligibility as an affected domestic producer, and qualifying expenditures incurred since the issuance of the order. The Commissioner will distribute funds from assessed duties to affected domestic producers based on certifications. Special accounts will be established in the Treasury for each antidumping duty order or finding. The Commissioner will establish special accounts in the Treasury for each antidumping or countervailing duty order. All duties assessed will be deposited into these accounts, and regulations will dictate the distribution of funds from these accounts. Special accounts will terminate once the related order or finding ends. The account established for antidumping or countervailing duty orders will be terminated once all duties are collected, and a final opportunity for distribution is provided. Any unclaimed amounts after 90 days will be deposited into the Treasury's general fund. A conforming amendment will be made to the Tariff Act of 1930. The amendments made by this section regarding dumping and subsidy offset will apply to duty assessments from October 1, 1996 onwards.
